required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Muscle Relax Affects Outcomes of Robotic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Neuromuscular Blockade Protocol on Perioperative Outcomes of Robotic Laparoscopic Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: During robotic laparoscopic surgery, a high intraperitoneal pressure may result in high airway pressure and inadequate perfusion of the abdominal organs, and as a result the postoperative outcomes. Degree of neuromuscular blockade (NMB) can affect the intraperitoneal pressure. In this study, the patients undergoing robotic laparoscopic surgery will be assigned to deep NMB group and moderate NMB group. Perioperative outcomes including maximal intraperitoneal pressure, maximal intraoptic pressure, quality of emergence, postoperative pain, and incidence of postoperative respiratory complication will be compared. The results of this study will provide evidence for optimizing NMB protocol of robotic laparoscopic surgery.

study_design_info.masking_description: Muscle relaxant will be given by a specific investigator that is not involved in anesthesia and outcome assessment

primary_outcome.measure: incidence of postoperative major respiratory complications
primary_outcome.time_frame: from end of surgery to discharge, at an average of 4 days

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from establishment of pneumoperitoneum to end of pneumoperitoneum, at an average of 3 hours
secondary_outcome.description: airway pressure is titrated to as low as possible as long as the end tidal carbon dioxide partial pressure is lower than 40 mmHg

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from start of surgery to end of surgery, at an average of 3.5 hours
secondary_outcome.description: cerebral oxygen saturation is continuously monitored during surgery

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from start of surgery to end of surgery, at an average of 3.5 hours
secondary_outcome.description: intraocular pressure is monitored every 10 minutes during surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: number of surgeon asking for improving muscle relax
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from start of surgery to end of surgery, at an average of 3.5 hours
secondary_outcome.description: when the surgeon is unsatisfied with the muscle relax, he can tell the anesthetist

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from end of sevoflurane inhalation to extubation, at an average of 20 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: criteria of extubation: spontaneous respiratory rate>10 per minute and end tidal carbon dioxide partial pressure<45mmHg

secondary_outcome.measure: incidence of nausea and vomiting in post-anesthesia care unit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from admittance to post-anesthesia care unit(PACU) to discharge from PACU, at an average of 30 minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: incidence of shoulder pain in 24 hours after surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from end of surgery to 24 hours after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: incidence of residual neuromuscular blockade in the post-anesthesia care unit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from admittance to post-anesthesia care unit(PACU) to discharge from PACU, at an average of 30 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: residual neuromuscular blockade is defined as time of head-lift or limb-lift<10 seconds

secondary_outcome.measure: visual analogue scale at 24 hours after surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of surgery to 24 hours after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: the patients are asked to mark the score they feel, 0 is no pain,100 is untolerated pain

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of the surgery to discharge,at an average of 4 days
secondary_outcome.description: the expense from immediately after surgery to discharge

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from end of surgery to discharge,at an average of 4 days
secondary_outcome.description: the patient is asked to give a score between 0 and 10, 0 means not satisfied,10 means totally satisfied.

arm_group.description: Rocuronium, a neuromuscular blocking agent will be given by continuous infusion at a dose that reaction to train of four (TOF) stimulation is depressed to zero
Rocuronium, a neuromuscular blocking agent will be given at a dose by intermittent injection that reaction to train of four (TOF) stimulation is kept 1 to 2

intervention.description: rocuronium is a neuromuscular blocking agent with a duration of 40 minutes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients scheduled for elective robotic laparoscopic surgery under general anesthesia
- American Society of Anesthesiologists status 1-2
- Body mass index of 18-30kg/m2
- Patients scheduled to be positioned in trendelenburg position during surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients allergic to rocuronium
- Patients with neuromuscular dysfunction
- Patients with existed pulmonary diseases
- Patients with hepatic or renal dysfunction

reference.citation: Van Wijk RM, Watts RW, Ledowski T, Trochsler M, Moran JL, Arenas GW. Deep neuromuscular block reduces intra-abdominal pressure requirements during laparoscopic cholecystectomy: a prospective observational study. Acta Anaesthesiol Scand. 2015 Apr;59(4):434-40. doi: 10.1111/aas.12491. Epub 2015 Feb 13.

Martini CH, Boon M, Bevers RF, Aarts LP, Dahan A. Evaluation of surgical conditions during laparoscopic surgery in patients with moderate vs deep neuromuscular block. Br J Anaesth. 2014 Mar;112(3):498-505. doi: 10.1093/bja/aet377. Epub 2013 Nov 15.

Barrio J, Errando CL, García-Ramón J, Sellés R, San Miguel G, Gallego J. Influence of depth of neuromuscular blockade on surgical conditions during low-pressure pneumoperitoneum laparoscopic cholecystectomy: A randomized blinded study. J Clin Anesth. 2017 Nov;42:26-30. doi: 10.1016/j.jclinane.2017.08.005. Epub 2017 Aug 30.

Torensma B, Martini CH, Boon M, Olofsen E, In 't Veld B, Liem RS, Knook MT, Swank DJ, Dahan A. Deep Neuromuscular Block Improves Surgical Conditions during Bariatric Surgery and Reduces Postoperative Pain: A Randomized Double Blind Controlled Trial. PLoS One. 2016 Dec 9;11(12):e0167907. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0167907. eCollection 2016.

patient_data.ipd_description: After publishing, data of the primary endpoint and second endpoints can be shared with other researchers
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: When the results have been published in peer-reviewed journals, the data will be available. The planned time frame will be 5 years.
